leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 85] s 85 Trial without jury unless jury required in interests of justice

leg:heading.title: Trial without jury unless jury required in interests of justice

p.text: Proceedings in any Division are to be tried without a jury, unless the Court orders otherwise.
The Court may make an order under subsection (1) that proceedings are to be tried with a jury if:
any party to the proceedings:
files a requisition for trial with a jury; and
pays the fee prescribed by the regulations made under section 18 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005; and
the Court is satisfied that the interests of justice require a trial by jury in the proceedings.
[subs (2) am Act No 28 of 2005 Sch 5, effective 15 August 2005]
The rules may prescribe the time within which a requisition must be filed for the purposes of subsection (2)(a).
A fee paid under this section is to be treated as costs in the proceedings, unless the Court orders otherwise.
In any proceedings in which the Court has ordered a trial by jury, the following questions of fact must be tried without the jury:
questions of fact on a defence arising under section 63(5) or 64(1)(c) of the Workers’ Compensation Act 1926 or section 151Z(1)(e) of the Workers Compensation Act 1987;
any other question of fact ordered by the Court.
This section does not apply to proceedings in any Division for defamation.
Section 21 of the Defamation Act 2005 makes provision for jury trials in defamation proceedings.
[subs (6) insrt Act 77 of 2005 s 48 and Sch 6, effective 1 January 2006]
[s 85 subst Act 124 of 2001 s 1 and Sch 2]

text.emph: All legislation relevant prior to 18 January 2002 appears below:

p.text: Subject to sections 86 , 87 and 88 , proceedings in any Division shall be tried without a jury, unless the Court otherwise orders.
The Court may order that any questions of fact in any proceedings be tried before any other questions of fact in the proceedings.

Where the Court makes an order under subsection (1) or section 87(1) , or where proceedings under section 88 are set down for trial, the plaintiff shall pay the fee prescribed for the purpose of section 86(1) and shall not be entitled to take any further step in the proceedings until the fee is paid.
[subs (3) insrt Act 18 of 1977 s 78(3) and Sch 7]
The fee paid under this section or section 86(1) shall be treated as costs in the proceedings, unless the Court otherwise orders.
[subs (4) insrt Act 18 of 1977 s 78(3) and Sch 7]

heading.title: Discretion to order trial by jury

p.text: The section permits a discretionary order for trial by jury in any proceedings, other than defamation proceedings involving issues of fact. Under s 86 there is a “reverse” discretion to dispense with trial by jury in defamation cases. (The section reflects the wider discretion which applied under the repealed s 89 , to a wider class of common law proceedings.) In the exercise of that discretion the normal incidents of jury trial (for example, lengthened hearing time, consequential cost, and potential disruption of the court lists) are impermissible considerations, and the discretion is to be exercised having regard to the circumstances of the particular case: Pambula District Hospital v Herriman (1988) 14 NSWLR 387 . The “interests of justice” criterion for the exercise of the discretion conferred by the present rule is probably also intended to focus on the circumstances of the particular case, so as to preclude any generally perceived disadvantages of jury trial from being determinative considerations. However, while those considerations may not be determinative, they may have practical implications for the parties: Stankowski v Commonwealth [2003] NSWSC 923; BC200305951 at [26] ; and for that reason, become relevant considerations in the exercise of the discretion: see by way of analogy Patton v Buchanan Borehole Collieries Pty Ltd (1993) 178 CLR 14; 112 ALR 378 . The power to order trial by jury probably does not preclude a subsequent order being made discharging the jury, and permitting the continuation of the proceedings before a judge alone.

For a discussion of the case law and statutory application of the meaning and application of “interests of justice” criterion see Maroubra Rugby League Football Club Inc v Malo [2007] NSWCA 39; BC200701510 at [10]ff per Mason P (personal injury in amateur sport — application for jury trial refused). Discussed also are Stalyce Holdings (Australia) Pty Ltd v Cetec Pty Ltd (2002) ATPR ¶41-866; [2002] FCA 278; BC200201015 (application to transfer proceedings including defamation claim from Federal Court to NSW Supreme Court on the basis that a jury trial was more readily available — application refused); Muir v Council for Trinity Grammar School [2005] NSWSC 555; BC200504120 (Hall J) (negligence claim — application for jury trial refused); Cross v Theiss Pty Ltd (2007) NSW ConvR ¶56-173; [2006] NSWSC 1465; BC200611294 (Adams J) (industrial accident resulting in personal injuries — jury trial ordered).

There has been some debate about whether the power in s 85(2) is in the nature of a discretion or a duty to act if the conditions in subs (2) are satisfied: see Finance Facilities Pty Ltd v FCT (1971) 127 CLR 106; 45 ALJR 615; BC7100680 ; Samad v District Court of NSW (2002) 209 FLR 140; Leach v R (2007) 232 ALR 325; 81 ALJR 598; [2007] HCA 3; BC200700300 ; Maroubra Rugby League Football Club Inc v Malo [2007] NSWCA 39; BC200701510 at [14], [40] and compare “may” in s 85(3) with “must” in s 85(5). Whatever its nature the power is only available to be exercised if the conditions in subs (2) are met (especially the condition that the court must be satisfied that the interests of justice require a trial by jury).

Section 85(5) means that the presence of particular complex factual issues does not necessarily preclude an order for trial by jury, because those issues can be tried without the jury: Maroubra Rugby League Football Club Inc v Malo [2007] NSWCA 39; BC200701510 at [15] .
See r 29.1(6) of the UCPR for the time limit refered to in s 85(3).

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 90.5] General verdicts — the judge's role

p.text: A jury's general verdict must be clearly stated and the trial judge has a duty to assist the jury in ensuring the verdict is unambiguous: Bromley v Tonkin (1987) 11 NSWLR 211 at 236 . This obligation may require the judge to ignore a qualification the jury places on its general verdict: Mercer v Cmr for Road Transport and Tramways (1936) 56 CLR 580; [1937] ALR 133 (verdict for plaintiff with a qualification that the defendant was not negligent); Mifsud v Commonwealth [1968] 2 NSWR 83 (verdict for defendant with a qualification awarding damages to the plaintiff). It may also oblige the judge to refuse to accept a proffered verdict: Gibbons v Howley [1990] VR 762 at 765 ; and to question the jury in order to determine the meaning the jury intended and provide them with an opportunity of amending the verdict to overcome the effect of a manifest error or mistake: Mourani v Jeldi Manufacturing Pty Ltd (1983) 50 ALR 519; 57 ALJR 825 ; Bradbury v NZ Loan and Mercantile Agency Co Ltd (1926) 27 SR (NSW) 15 ; Gibbons v Howley [1990] VR 762 at 765 . But once the jury's verdict is clearly expressed, the trial judge is not entitled to engage in further questioning in an attempt to determine the reasons for the verdict: Mourani v Jeldi Manufacturing Pty Ltd (1983) 50 ALR 519; 57 ALJR 825 ; Bromley v Tonkin (1987) 11 NSWLR 211 at 233 .

It is often desirable to have a jury provide separate answers to specific questions rather than simply return a general verdict. (The jury should also be asked to return a general verdict — though this may be dispensed with if no objection is taken: Bromley v Tonkin (1987) 11 NSWLR 211 at 233 ; Anderson v Ntzounas [1988] VR 748 .) Such a course might be required because of the complexity of the issues involved or to facilitate the exercise of the discretion in CPA s 100 to award interest, for example by distinguishing between past and future loss: Morosi v Mirror Newspapers Ltd [1977] 2 NSWLR 749 at 761; Otis Elevators Pty Ltd v Zitis (1986) 5 NSWLR 171. This section provides a specific authority for such a course. It does not entitle a judge to interrogate the jury about their reasons either for bringing in a general verdict or for the answers to a particular question: Assaf v Skalkos [2000] NSWSC 418; BC200002902 . Nor does it compel the jury to respond to any such interrogation. But subject to that prohibition, the judge is entitled, and indeed obliged, to ensure that the answers the jury gives are clearly stated: Mourani v Jeldi Manufacturing Pty Ltd (1983) 50 ALR 519; 57 ALJR 825 ; and in discharging that obligation the judge may embark on a degree of questioning to clarify the jury's answers: Cunningham v Ryan (1919) 27 CLR 294 at 300–6; 25 ALR 367 . If, at a trial with a jury, a verdict is given or a finding or assessment is made, the court may give judgment as it thinks fit despite the verdict, finding or assessment: r 29.11 UCPR.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 90.15] Inconsistency arising from the jury's answers

heading.title: Inconsistency arising from the jury's answers

p.text: Inconsistency in the answers given by a jury to particular questions may justify rejection of the verdict on appeal where the inconsistency demonstrates the jury fell into error by, for example, failing to take account of a trial judge's direction: Otis Elevators Pty Ltd v Zitis (1986) 5 NSWLR 171 (alleged inconsistency between general damages and damages for economic loss); Quinn v Rocla Concrete Pipes Ltd (1986) NSWJB 234 (award of general damages but rejection of special damages including agreed out of pocket expenses); Cousins v Bradford Kendall Foundries Pty Ltd (1986) 7 NSWLR 428; Moon v Lugame Pty Ltd (t/as Bullitt Transmissions, Dubbo) (NSWCA, Kirby P, Mahoney and Clarke JJ, CA 40461/90, 2 December 1992, unreported, BC9201448) (jury fixing special damages but failing to award general damages). However, in these cases the court will endeavour to construe the answers consistently and deficiencies in the answers to questions will not justify setting aside the jury's verdict unless the answers are necessarily inconsistent: Brancato v Australian Telecommunications Commission (1987) 7 NSWLR 30 at 32.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 90.20] Specific questions where matter withdrawn

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 90.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 UCPR 29.11.

A judge should be asked to leave questions to the jury under this section where the judge proposes to give judgment notwithstanding verdict under UCPR 29.11 or where he or she proposes to make a ruling that an issue be withdrawn from the jury. The reason for this practice being adopted is to allow the verdict or answer to be available on appeal and to avoid the need for a retrial: Turner v Ku-ring-gai Municipal Council (1990) 72 LGRA 60; 12 MVR 321 .
